title: VW Boss Denies Firm Deliberately Misled People
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Oct 15, 2015, 12:04 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 26 mins VW Boss Denies Firm Deliberately Misled People By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 10 minutes ago View Photo 

It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is "implausible" and "absolutely inconceivable" that the VW emissions scandal was a delibrate attempt by the firm to mislead people, its UK boss has said. 
But Paul Willis, appearing before the Commons environmental audit committee, admitted the firm had fallen short of customers' expectations. 
He said VW "really want to put these things right" and that it would "do the right thing" for customers. 
He told MPs he did not think more revelations would come out over the 'defeat devices' fitted to an estimated 11 million diesel vehicles - including 1.2 million in Britain. 
The head of the UK car industry body, the SMMT, also told MPs he had had assurances that other car makers were not involved. 
Volkswagen (Other OTC: VLKAF - news ) has been in turmoil since admitting last month its 2009 to 2015 models were hiding their true level of emissions from US regulators. 
"I can speak for the whole group when I can say Volkswagen is deeply sorry," VW's UK boss told MPs. 
He added: "Since last weekend we've started to send personal letters to each and every affected customer. 
"Constant communication will be ongoing throughout the remedy process." 
It comes as a survey found nine out of 10 Volkswagen drivers in the UK whose vehicles could be affected think they should get compensation. 
Consumer group Which? found that out of more than 2,000 motorists who own a diesel manufactured between 2008 and 2015, 90% believe they should get compensation. 
Mr Willis told MPs he had read the article and "fully" understood its findings. 
However he added it was "premature" to talk about compensation for potential falls in the value of customers' cars. 
The emissions scandal has battered VW's share price, forced out its chief executive and prompted investigations around the world. 
Its US boss, Michael Horn, has claimed only "a couple of software engineers" were responsible. 
Germany's automotive watchdog, the KBA, announced on Thursday it would force the company to recall 2.4 million vehicles in the country. 
Volkswagen had proposed customers return their vehicles voluntarily. The recall will start at the beginning of 2016. 
Some 2.4 million cars in Germany are thought to be affected, according to transport minister Alexander Dobrindt.
